title: The Gregorian Calendar
text: The Gregorian calendar is the most widely used civil calendar in the world. It was introduced in October 1582 by Pope Gregory XIII as a modification of, and replacement for, the Julian calendar. The principal change was to space leap years differently to make the average calendar year 365.2425 days long, more closely approximating the 365.2422-day tropical year.

title: The Julian Calendar
text: The Julian calendar was a reform of the Roman calendar introduced by Julius Caesar in 46 BC. It took effect in 45 BC and remained the dominant calendar in the Western world for over 1600 years until 1582. The Julian calendar has a regular year of 365 days divided into 12 months, with a leap day added to February every four years.

title: Unix Epoch
text: The Unix epoch is 00:00:00 UTC on 1 January 1970. This date and time is the point of reference for measuring Unix time, which counts the number of seconds elapsed since this moment (excluding leap seconds). Unix time is widely used in computing systems and programming languages.

title: Leap Year
text: A leap year is a calendar year that contains an additional day compared to a common year. The 366th day is added to keep the calendar year synchronized with the astronomical year or seasonal year. In the Gregorian calendar, most years divisible by 4 are leap years, with exceptions for years divisible by 100 unless also divisible by 400.

title: Atomic Clock
text: An atomic clock is a type of clock that uses the resonance frequencies of atoms as its resonator. The first accurate atomic clock was built in 1955 by Louis Essen and Jack Parry at the National Physical Laboratory in the UK. Atomic clocks are the most accurate time and frequency standards known, and are used to define the second in the International System of Units.

title: Coordinated Universal Time (UTC)
text: Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) is the primary time standard by which the world regulates clocks and time. It is within about one second of mean solar time at 0Â° longitude, and is not adjusted for daylight saving time. UTC was established in 1972, replacing Greenwich Mean Time as the international time standard.

title: Daylight Saving Time
text: Daylight saving time (DST) is the practice of advancing clocks during warmer months so that darkness falls at a later clock time. The typical implementation advances clocks one hour in spring and adjusts them back in autumn. The modern idea of daylight saving was first proposed in 1895 by George Vernon Hudson and was first implemented during World War I.

title: Time Zones
text: A time zone is an area which observes a uniform standard time for legal, commercial and social purposes. Time zones tend to follow the boundaries between countries and their subdivisions instead of strictly following longitude. The world is divided into 24 time zones, each generally 15 degrees of longitude apart, corresponding to a one-hour difference in time.

title: Maya Calendar
text: The Maya calendar is a system of calendars used in pre-Columbian Mesoamerica and in many modern communities in the Guatemalan highlands, Veracruz, Oaxaca and Chiapas, Mexico. The Maya calendar consists of several cycles or counts of different lengths. The most commonly known Maya cyclical calendars are the Haab, the Tzolk'in, and the Long Count.

title: Year 2000 Problem (Y2K)
text: The Year 2000 problem, also known as the Y2K bug, was a computer flaw related to the formatting and storage of calendar data for dates on and after January 1, 2000. Many programs represented four-digit years with only the final two digits, making the year 2000 indistinguishable from 1900. The problem was largely resolved through extensive testing and code fixes.

title: Chinese Calendar
text: The Chinese calendar is a lunisolar calendar which identifies years, months, and days according to astronomical phenomena. It is used for determining the dates of traditional Chinese holidays. The calendar consists of repeating cycles of 60 years, with each year being associated with one of the twelve animals of the Chinese zodiac and one of the five elements.

title: Big Ben
text: Big Ben is the nickname for the Great Bell of the Great Clock of Westminster, and by extension the clock tower itself. The tower was completed in 1859 and the clock first rang on 31 May 1859. Big Ben is considered one of the most accurate public clocks in the world and has been keeping time for over 160 years.

title: Solar Time
text: Solar time is a calculation of the passage of time based on the position of the Sun in the sky. The fundamental unit of solar time is the day, which is the time it takes for the Sun to return to the same position in the sky. Mean solar time is the basis for civil time, while apparent solar time varies throughout the year due to Earth's elliptical orbit.

title: Leap Second
text: A leap second is a one-second adjustment that is occasionally applied to Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) to keep it close to mean solar time. The Earth's rotation is gradually slowing down, so leap seconds are added to compensate. Since 1972, a total of 27 leap seconds have been inserted, the most recent on December 31, 2016.

title: Sundial
text: A sundial is a device that tells the time of day when direct sunlight shines by the apparent position of the Sun in the sky. The oldest known sundial dates back to ancient Egypt around 1500 BC. Sundials were widely used to measure time before the development of mechanical clocks and remain popular as garden ornaments and educational tools.
